description: From Middle English soudeour, from Old French soudier or soudeour (“mercenary”), from Medieval Latin soldarius (“soldier (one having pay)”), from Late Latin solidus, a type of coin. Displaced Old English cempa (whence obsolete kemp).

entries.meaning: A member of a ground-based army, of any rank, but especially an enlisted member.
examples: I am a soldier and unapt to weep.

entries.meaning: (by extension, nonstandard) Any member of a military, regardless of specialty.
An enlisted member of a military service, as distinguished from a commissioned officer.
examples: It were meet that any one, before he came to be a captain, should have been a soldier.

entries.meaning: A member of the Salvation Army.
A low-ranking gangster or member of a gang, especially the mafia, who engages in physical conflict.
(Britain, Australia, New Zealand) A piece of buttered bread (or toast), cut into a long thin strip for dipping into a soft-boiled egg.
A term of approbation for a young boy.
Someone who fights or toils well.
examples: [L]et 'em know how important it is to have Runyon Avenue soldiers up in our corners; their loyalty to us is worth more than any award is.

entries.meaning: The red or cuckoo gurnard (Chelidonichthys cuculus).
One of the asexual polymorphic forms of termites, in which the head and jaws are very large and strong. The soldiers serve to defend the nest.
(slang, dated) A red herring (cured kipper with flesh turned red).

verbs.description: soldier (third-person singular simple present soldiers, present participle soldiering, simple past and past participle soldiered)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To continue steadfast; to keep striving.
(intransitive) To intentionally restrict labor productivity; to work at the slowest rate that goes unpunished.
(transitive, slang) To take a ride on (another person's horse) without permission.
